org.jdesktop.core.animation.timing.interpolators
Class DiscreteInterpolator

java.lang.Object
  org.jdesktop.core.animation.timing.interpolators.DiscreteInterpolator
All Implemented Interfaces:
Interpolator
@Immutable
@Singleton
public final class DiscreteInterpolator
extends java.lang.Object
implements Interpolator

This class interpolates fractional values to animate movement in "discrete" steps. A discrete animation is defined to be one where the values during an animation do not change smoothly between the boundary values, but suddenly, at the boundary points. For example, a discrete animation with KeyFrames where the KeyTimes are {0, .5, 1.0} and the KeyValues are (0, 1, 2} would, during the animation, retain the value of 0 until half-way through the animation and 1 through the rest of the animation.

Because this class has no state, it is implemented as a singleton that is referenced using the getInstance() static method. The singleton instance is thread-safe.

Author:
Chet Haase

Method Detail

getInstance

public static DiscreteInterpolator getInstance()
Gets the single DiscreteInterpolator object.

Returns:
the single DiscreteInterpolator object.

interpolate

@RegionEffects(value="reads Instance")
public double interpolate(double fraction)
This method always returns 0 for inputs less than 1, which will force users of this interpolation to assign a value equal to the value at the beginning of this timing interval, which is the desired behavior for discrete animations. An input of 1 will return 1, since this means the end of the current interval (and start to the next interval).

Specified by:
interpolate in interface Interpolator
Parameters:
fraction - a value between 0 and 1, representing the elapsed fraction of a time interval (either an entire animation cycle or an interval between two KeyTimes, depending on where this Interpolator has been set)
Returns:
a number representing the start of the current interval, usually 0, but if fraction == 1, returns 1.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
